qas.question: What is the most reliable measure of pain?
What do health-care professionals tend to underestimate?
What did Margo McCaffery introduce in 1968?
What scale might a patient be asked to locate their pain on?
What are patients asked to use the McGill Pain Questionnaire to indicate?

answers.text: which words best describe their pain

plausible_answers.text: the most reliable measure of pain

qas.question: What is a person's health care report?

plausible_answers.text: Pain is whatever the experiencing person says it is, existing whenever he says it does"

qas.question: What is the definition Margo McCaffery gave for pain in 1986?
What is the number range on the McCaffery Pain scale?

context: A <a0_0>person's self-report<a0_0/> is <b5_0>the most reliable measure of pain<b5_0/>, with health care professionals tending to underestimate <a1_0>severity<a1_0/>. A <a2_0>definition of pain<a2_0/> widely employed in nursing, emphasizing its subjective nature and the importance of believing patient reports, was introduced by <b6_0>Margo McCaffery<b6_0/> in 1968: "<b7_0>Pain is whatever the experiencing person says it is, existing whenever he says it does"<b7_0/>. To assess intensity, the patient may be asked to locate their pain on a scale of <a3_0><b8_0>0 to 10<b8_0/><a3_0/>, with 0 being no pain at all, and 10 the worst pain they have ever felt. Quality can be established by having the patient complete the McGill Pain Questionnaire indicating <a4_0>which words best describe their pain<a4_0/>.
